metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Assessee

facts.text: Question referred by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal for the opinion of the Bombay High Court: Whether on the facts of the case, income, profits and gains in respect of sales made to Government of India was received in British India within the meaning of Section 4(1) of the Act?
The High Court answered the question in the negative for reasons set out in its judgment considering this case as well as the case out of which Appeal No. 19 of 1953 came to be filed before us.

The facts found in this case are similar to those found in Civil Appeal No. 19 of 1953 Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Messrs. Ogale Glass Works Ltd., except that: 1. all cheques were made non-negotiable, 2. credit was given by the bank to the assessee before collection, 3. there was no finding that the assessee gave credit to the Government for the amount of the cheque immediately on receipt thereof.
Learned counsel on either side did not suggest that the differences would make any difference in the answer to the referred question which is the same as in the other appeal.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts of the case, income, profits and gains in respect of sales made to Government of India was received in British India within the meaning of Section 4(1) of the Act?

petitioner_arguments.text: Learned counsel did not suggest that the differences in facts would make any difference in the answer to the referred question.

respondent_arguments.text: Learned counsel did not suggest that the differences in facts would make any difference in the answer to the referred question.

court_reasoning.text: That being the position, this case is governed by the judgment which has just been pronounced by us in the other appeal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The differences numbered above would [not] make any difference in the answer to the referred question.

holdings.text: We accordingly allow the appeal and answer the referred question in the affirmative.
